home.activation: Enter your activation code to continue

data.heading: Prepare the Ryzodeg™ FlexTouch™ pen
data.title: Check Your Pen
content: Read the label to check you have the right type of insulin. Pull off the pen cap. Make sure the insulin is clear and colourless.

data.title: Attach a new needle
content: Tear off the paper tab. Push the needle straight onto the pen. Turn until it is on tight. Pull off both needle caps.

data.title: Prime the pen
content: Turn the dose selector to select 2 units. Press and hold in the dose button. Make sure a drop appears.

data.heading: Give your injection
data.title: Select your dose
content: Turn the dose selector to select the dose you need to inject.

data.title: Inject your dose
content: Insert the needle. Press and hold the dose button down. After the dose counter reaches 0, leave the needle under the skin for at least 6 seconds. Count slowly to 6 to make sure you get your full dose.

data.title: Remove the needle
content: Lead the needle tip into the outer needle cap on a flat surface. Once the needle is covered, carefully push the outer needle cap completely on. Unscrew the needle and dispose of it. Replace the pen cap.

how_to_use_novopen.title: How to use NovoPen® 4 with Ryzodeg™ Penfill®

con.title: Prepare your pen
content: Pull off the pen cap.
Twist off the cartridge holder.
The piston rod may stick out of your pen. If so, push it in until it stops.

Take a new insulin cartridge and check that:
- It contains the correct insulin, which looks like as it should.
- It has no cracks or damage.

data.title: Insert the cartridge
content: Slide the cartridge into the cartridge holder with the threaded end first.
Twist the cartridge holder back on.

data.title: Attach a new needle
content: Take a new needle, and tear off the paper tab.
Push the needle straight onto the pen. Turn until it is on tight.
Pull off the outer needle cap and save it.
Pull off the inner needle cap and throw it away

data.title: Test the insulin flow
content: ALWAYS test the flow before you inject. Keep testing until insulin squirts from the needle tip. This makes sure that any gap and air bubbles are removed and that insulin is getting through the needle.
Select 2 units and press the dose button until the dose counter shows '0'.
If no insulin appears, repeat the insulin flow test. The insulin flow test. The insulin flow test is complete when you see insulin squirt.

data.title: Select your dose
content: Pull out the dose button, if it is not already out.
Make sure the dose counter shows '0' before you start.
Turn the dose button to select the dose you need. You can turn forwards or backwards.

data.title: Inject your dose
content: Insert the needle into your skin and press the dose button until the dose counter shows '0'
Then wait and count slowly to 6 before you remove the needle from your skin
Safely remove and throw away the needle after placing the outer needle cap. Put the pen cap back on it. Do not store your pen with a needle attached

novomix_you.title: What is Ryzodeg™ and how does it work?

description.text: Ryzodeg™ is an insulin designed to work similarly to the way your body works when it releases its own natural insulin to reduce your blood sugar levels. This is important throughout the day, including after main meals, when your blood sugar levels are higher.

data.title: An insulin for the entire day (24 hours):
content: Helps your body control your blood sugar levels throughout the day and night

data.title: An insulin for your meal(s):
content: Covers your blood sugar levels after the meal(s) it was taken with

imgcon.text: Please read patient information leaflet for additional information.

novomix_you.title: Where to inject Ryzodeg™?

list: The best places to inject are the front of your waist  (abdomen), upper arms, or the front of your thighs (see diagram below)
Ryzodeg™ is given as an injection under the skin. Do not inject into a vein or muscle (Tip: Pinch the skin at the injection site to avoid injecting into a vein or muscle)
Each day, it is recommended to change the site on your body where you inject

novomix_you.con: Please read patient information leaflet for additional information.

novomix_you.title: How to store Ryzodeg™?

description.text: Keep Ryzodeg™ out of the sight and reach of children. Do not use this medication after the expiry date, which is stated on the pen label and carton, after 'EXP.'

data.title: Storage before first use:
list: Store in a refrigerator (2ºC to 8ºC) and keep away from the freezing element; do not freeze
Keep the cap on the pen in order to protect it from light

data.title: Storage after first opening or if carried as a spare:
list: Do not refrigerate. You can carry your Ryzodeg™ pen with you and keep it at room temperature (not above 30°C) for up to 4 weeks
Always keep the cap on the pen when you are not using it, in order to protect it from light

data.title: Disposal of pen:
list: Do not throw away any medication via waste water or household waste. Ask your pharmacist how to throw away medication you no longer use. These measures will help protect the environment
When your pen is empty and the needle has been disposed of safely, you can dispose of the pen in normal waste

novomix_you.con: Please read patient information leaflet for additional information.

data.title: Blood sugar (glucose)
data.text: The concentration of sugar in the bloodstream – the body’s main source of energy.

data.title: Hyperglycaemia
data.text: High blood glucose (sugar). Occurs in diabetes when there is a lack of insulin so glucose is not removed from the bloodstream.

data.title: Hypoglycaemia
data.text: Low blood glucose (sugar). Can be triggered by taking too much insulin, inadequate food intake or by participating in unusually strenuous or prolonged activity or exercise.

data.title: Insulin
data.text: A hormone produced by the beta cells in the pancreas. Needed to remove sugar from the bloodstream so other cells can use it as fuel.

data.title: Pancreas
data.text: An organ in the body that stretches across the back of the abdomen behind the stomach. The pancreas is where insulin and digestive enzymes are made.

list: Eat a wide variety of healthy foods.
Balance the number of calories with your activity level.
Choose foods rich in whole grains, vegetables, fruits and fat-free/low-fat milk products.
Eat lean meats, such as poultry and fish, and beans for protein.
Limit the amount of saturated fat and salt.
Cut down on added sugars.
Keep to sensible amounts of alcohol.
Have a proper breakfast every day to boost your body’s ability to burn energy.
Space your eating throughout the day and don’t skip meals.

counselling.title: Myths and facts about diabetes
counselling.heading: Not everything you hear about diabetes is true. Here are some myths you may hear – and the facts you should know.

data.question: Diabetes is a one-way street to bad health problems.
data.answer: You can go in another direction! If you follow your diabetes care plan, you can often delay or prevent problems from diabetes.

data.question: It’s your own fault that you have diabetes.
data.answer: Diabetes isn’t anyone’s fault. There are multiple causes of diabetes. Your eating and activity choices can play a role in your blood sugar control. But it’s not the whole story.

data.question: I have to take insulin. My diabetes must be really bad.
data.answer: Not always. Everyone with type 1 diabetes needs to take insulin. Insulin can be one of the medications to help control your diabetes. With progression of diabetes, the beta cells in the pancreas make less and less insulin.  Most pills given to patients with type 2 diabetes work to help the pancreas release more insulin. However, as diabetes progresses, these pills may not work to control blood sugar levels.

data.title: A typical diabetes care plan includes:
list: A meal plan
A physical activity plan
A plan for how and when to check your blood sugar
Your personal blood sugar goals
When to take your diabetes medicines
Other health goals (such as managing your weight and blood pressure)
A schedule for regular health checkups
Ways to deal with stress

data.title: As part of your care plan, be sure to keep track of your ABCs:
list: A1C
Blood pressure
Cholesterol

counselling.title: Knowing your A1C
counselling.description: The A1C test measures your estimated average blood sugar level over the past 2 to 3 months. It’s like a 'memory' of your blood sugar levels. It shows how well you’re controlling your blood sugar levels over time. Your A1C and your blood sugar levels go up and down together. Here is how they go together:

counselling.title: Recognizing high blood sugar
counselling.cause: Too much food, too little insulin, illness or stress
counselling.onset: Gradual, may progress to diabetic coma

data.title: If over 200 mg/dl for several tests, Call your doctor

counselling.title: Recognizing low blood sugar
counselling.cause: Too little food, too much insulin or diabetes medicine or extra exercise
counselling.onset: Sudden, may progress to diabetic shock

data.title: Drink half glass of orange juice or skimmed milk with sugar or eat 3-4 candies
TEST BLOOD GLUCOSE, If symptoms don't stop, call your doctor
Within 30 minutes after symptoms go away eat a light snack
Wash your feet daily. Test the water temperature with an elbow to avoid scalding accidents.
Dry your feet – especially between toes. Cut and file toenails straight across. Contact a chiropodist if you have any problems.
Apply moisturiser (or hand cream) to keep your skin supple and prevent cracking.
It is ESSENTIAL to examine your feet daily for cuts or anything unusual.
Breaks in the skin should be covered with a dry, sterile dressing. Do NOT burst blisters but seek help from your doctor.
NEVER use sharp instruments on your feet. Do NOT use corn plasters etc. as they contain ACIDS. If any problems occur seek advice from your GP, diabetic clinic or chiropodist.
AVOID direct heat and hot water bottles – loss of pain and temperature sensitivity make these dangerous.
Remember DIABETES can affect the rate of healing and breaks in the skin may take a little longer to heal. Older people are most at risk.
Ensure shoes fit well – have your feet measured. Remember shoes must fit feet – NOT VICE VERSA. Never go barefoot.
Check inside shoes for sharp objects, etc. Also check inside socks for small things like a pebble etc. to avoid irritation which can lead to a sore.
Keep in touch with a chiropodist who is there to advise on foot care.
